Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of an X-ray/Ultraviolet Photoelectron Spectrometer (XPS/UPS)

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1337374
Fortner

This proposal requests funding for the acquisition of a X-ray and ultraviolet photoelectron spectrometer (XPS/UPS) for Washington University in St. Louis. The greater St. Louis metropolitan region does not have an XPS/UPS instrument within a 100 mile radius and this proposal therefore fills a critical gap in the advanced analytical needs of the region. The instrument will be housed, supported and staffed in the materials characterization area of the newly formed Institute of Materials Science and Engineering (IMSE) at Washington University. The system configuration requested is designed to facilitate a wide spectrum of research, supporting XPS/UPS needs for five regional universities and three multinational corporations in eastern Missouri and southern Illinois. The VersaProbe II will come equipped with an Al K�� x-ray source to help determine chemical states of surfaces a few nanometers deep. He I and II ultraviolet sources will provide information on the valence band of materials. The system will also be equipped with mapping and imaging capabilities in the XY direction and sputter capabilities which will afford depth analysis in the Z direction. A separate glove box with a portable transfer chamber will allow air or O2 sensitive samples to be prepared and delivered to the load lock of the XPS/UPS system without risking oxidation or degradation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This proposal was awarded for the acquisition of a X-ray and ultraviolet photoelectron spectrometer (XPS/UPS), specially a Physical Electronics® 5000 VersaProbe II Scanning ESCA (XPS) Microprobe, as part of a user facility Washington University in St. Louis. The greater St. Louis metropolitan region does not have an XPS/UPS facility within a 100 mile radius and this acquisition therefore fills a critical gap in the advanced analytical needs of the region. The instrument is housed, supported and staffed in the materials characterization facility of the newly formed Institute of Materials Science and Engineering (IMSE) at Washington University. The system configuration requested is designed to facilitate a wide spectrum of research, supporting XPS/UPS needs for five regional universities and three multinational corporations in eastern Missouri and southern Illinois. The VersaProbe II will come equipped with an Al Ka x-ray source to determine chemical states of surfaces a few nanometers deep. He I and II ultraviolet sources provide information on the valence band of materials. The system is also equipped with mapping and imaging capabilities in the XY direction and sputter capabilities which afford depth analysis in the Z direction. A separate glove box with a portable transfer chamber allows air or O2 sensitive samples to be prepared and delivered to the load lock of the XPS/UPS system without risking oxidation or degradation. Access and administrative support is provided through the IMSE with the instrument supervised by a steering committee consisting of the PIs and leadership from IMSE.  A dedicated technician manages the instrument and provide user training. The instrument is now available to academic and corporate users through a web-based scheduling system.  All users pay appropriate hourly usage fees to support the operation and maintenance of the instrument.

Intellectual Merit: The XPS/UPS system broadly advances research in the material and surface sciences at Washington University in St. Louis and the surrounding region. A considerable thrust and focus is provided with the newly opened IMSE at Washington University, which seeks to unify and organize materials centric research under one umbrella organization. The instrument facilitates materials research with a number of foci: the environmental chemistry of nanomaterials, creation and optimization of energy harvesting devices, design of inorganic and hybrid materials for sensor applications, contaminate fate in and removal from natural and engineered aquatic systems, development of novel electronic materials, biomineralization, creation of self-assemblaged monolayers for sensing and materials synthesis, and the development of novel energy storage materials. Many of the properties and hence performance of materials utilized in the above thrust areas are determined by their surface chemical states and structure. The XPS/UPS system provides the necessary analytical abilities to probe such information for a wide variety of naturally occurring and engineered materials systems. The XPS/UPS system is now playing a key, connecting role in contributing to advancing fundamental knowledge in the materials sciences and foster interdisciplinary growth of research activities.

Broader Impacts: The presence of an XPS/UPS system is now directly augmenting/enhancing the analytical capabilities and technical infrastructure of the region. Open access to the instrument through IMSE is fostering cross and multi-disciplinary collaboration(s) within Washington University and other institutions of higher learning.
